name: Datepicker
description: Calender
Documentation and examples for badges, our small count and labeling component.
name: Badge

description: Buttons will appear pressed (with a darker background, darker border, and inset shadow) when active. There’s no need to add a class to <button>s as they use a pseudo-class. However, you can still force the same active appearance with .active (and include the aria-pressed="true" attribute) should you need to replicate the state programmatically.
name: Active state

description: Create block level buttons—those that span the full width of a parent—by adding .vf-btn--block.
name: Full width buttons

description: Similar to the contextual text color classes, easily set the background of an element to any contextual class. Anchor components will darken on hover, just like the text classes. Background utilities do not set color, so in some cases you'll want to use .text-* utilities.
name: Background colour

description: Borders can be used to separate sections of a site or service.
name: Borders

description: To disable a drop-down, simply add the modifier class disabled to the vf-dropdown element, and change the data-control attribute to vf-dropdown-data-disabled
name: Disabled

description: To use the underline style, simply add the modifier class vf-dropdown--underline to the vf-dropdown element.
name: Underline style

description: To add checkboxes, simply add inputs before the label within the vf-dropdown-list-item element. The name attribute must be vf-dropdown-group, and the value attribute must be the same as the label.
name: With checkboxes

description: For grids that are the same from the smallest of devices to the largest, use the .vf-col and .vf-col-* classes. Specify a numbered class when you need a particularly sized column; otherwise, feel free to stick to .vf-col.
name: All breakpoints

description: For content areas that are supposed to bleed out of the standard container.
name: Bleed container

description: Breaking columns to a new line in flexbox requires a small hack: add an element with width: 100% wherever you want to wrap your columns to a new line. Normally this is accomplished with multiple .rows, but not every implementation method can account for this.
name: Column breaks

description: If more than 12 columns are placed within a single row, each group of extra columns will, as one unit, wrap onto a new line.
name: Column wrapping

description: For example, here are two grid layouts that apply to every device and viewport, from xs to xl. Add any number of unit-less classes for each breakpoint you need and every column will be the same width.
name: Equal width

description: Create equal-width columns that span multiple rows by inserting a .w-100 where you want the columns to break to a new line. Make the breaks responsive by mixing the .w-100 with some responsive display utilities.
name: Equal-width multi-row

description:
Gutters can be responsively adjusted by breakpoint-specific padding and negative margin utility classes. To change the gutters in a given row, pair a negative margin utility on the .row and matching padding utilities on the .vf-cols.

Here's an example of customizing the VF Design System grid at the large (lg) breakpoint and above. We've increased the .vf-col padding with .px-lg-5 and then counteracted that with .mx-lg-n5 on the parent .row.
name: Gutters

description: Vattenfall's grid system uses a series of containers, rows, and columns to layout and align content. It's built with flexbox and is fully responsive. Below is an example and an in-depth look at how the grid comes together.
name: How it works

description: With the move to flexbox in v4, you can use margin utilities like .mr-auto to force sibling columns away from one another.
name: Margin utilities

description: Don't want your columns to simply stack in some grid tiers? Use a combination of different classes for each tier as needed. See the example below for a better idea of how it all works.
name: Mix and match

description: The gutters between columns in our predefined grid classes can be removed with .no-gutters. This removes the negative margins from .row and the horizontal padding from all immediate children columns.
name: No gutters

description: Move columns to the right using .vf-offset-md-* classes. These classes increase the left margin of a column by * columns. For example, .vf-offset-md-4 moves .vf-col-md-4 over four columns.
name: Offset classes

description: Use .order- classes for controlling the visual order of your content. These classes are responsive, so you can set the order by breakpoint (e.g., .order-1.order-md-2). Includes support for 1 through 12 across all five grid tiers.
name: Order classes

description: Auto-layout for flexbox grid columns also means you can set the width of one column and have the sibling columns automatically resize around it. You may use predefined grid classes (as shown below), grid mixins, or inline widths. Note that the other columns will resize no matter the width of the center column.
name: Setting one column width

description: Using a single set of .vf-col-sm-* classes, you can create a basic grid system that starts out stacked and becomes horizontal at the small breakpoint (sm).
name: Stacked to horizontal

description: The regular container for all standard content.
name: Standard container

description: Used for content heavy pages etc.
name: Tight container

description: Use col-{breakpoint}-auto classes to size columns based on the natural width of their content.
name: Variable width content

description: To display an error state, simply add the modifier class vf-input--error to the input element
name: Error state

description: To use a number input, change the input type to number. The de/increment will be controlled by the step value, if given.
name: Number

description: Example of input with CSS placeholder. Add vf-input--css-placeholder class and a placeholder value (it will be hidden but requires a value to work).
name: Standard with CSS placeholder triggers

description: To use a textarea, simply exchange the input element for a textarea one.
name: Textarea

description: To display a warning state, simply add the modifier class vf-input--warning to the input element
name: Warning state

description: To add a Tooltip icon and text, simply add a data-tooltip data attribute with the required text to the input element. Tooltip styling classes must be applied to the input element. Available options
name: With tooltip

description: Are the components in this case. For example a modal window.
name: Blocks

description: All components are named after CSS BEM standard.
name: Component naming

description: The parts that make up the component. For example the modal window title, close button etc.
name: Elements

description: Handles different stylistic or functional variants of the same element. Example
name: Modifiers

description: Specific icons are automatically added to the following filetypes if the href property ends in any of the following:
name: File list

description: Available classes:
name: Responsive utility classes

description: These classes for using percentages of the current window height are available:
name: VH classes

description: Available classes: .w-25 .w-50 .w-75 .w-100 .w-auto
name: Width classes

description: Here are some representative examples of these classes:
name: Examples

description: Additionally, VF Design System also includes an .mx-auto class for horizontally centering fixed-width block level content—that is, content that has display: block and a width set—by setting the horizontal margins to auto.
name: Horizontal centering

description:
In CSS, margin properties can utilize negative values (padding cannot). As of 4.2, we've added negative margin utilities for every non-zero integer size listed above (e.g., 1, 2, 3, 4, 5). These utilities are ideal for customizing grid column gutters across breakpoints.

The syntax is nearly the same as the default, positive margin utilities, but with the addition of n before the requested size. Here's an example class that's the opposite of .mt-1:
name: Negative margin

description: Spacing utilities that apply to all breakpoints, from xs to xl, have no breakpoint abbreviation in them. This is because those classes are applied from min-width: 0 and up, and thus are not bound by a media query. The remaining breakpoints, however, do include a breakpoint abbreviation.
name: Notation

description:
Assign responsive-friendly margin or padding values to an element or a subset of its sides with shorthand classes. Includes support for individual properties, all properties, and vertical and horizontal properties.

 Vattenfall uses four default custom spacers, called Small, Medium, Large and Extra Large.
name: Spacers
Buttons
description: Buttons indicate actions on the page. Each of our button types have specific purposes that are used consistently. Individual button types are documented below, but the following guidelines will help you understand basic functionality for all of our buttons.
Primary buttons should be used for primary calls to action
name: Primary Buttons

description: The yellow button indicated our main focus action. There is only one yellow button per component. If you need more buttons in one component, use secondary buttons
name: Primary Buttons - blue

description: The yellow button indicated our main focus action. There is only one yellow button per component. If you need more buttons in one component, use secondary buttons
name: Primary Buttons - yellow

description: Outlined buttons (often called “ghost” buttons) are a step up in complexity and emphasis from a text button in button design. They typically indicate actions that are important but not the primary action on a page. Outlined buttons should be exactly that: an outline with no fill surrounding text that indicates an action.
name: Secondary Buttons

description: Black outlined buttons are used in combination with the yellow primary buttons.
name: Tertiary black - (outlined-button)

description: Blue outlined buttons are used in combination with the blue primary buttons.
name: Tertiary blue - (outlined-button)

description: Blue outlined buttons are used in combination with the blue primary buttons.
name: Tertiary blue - (outlined-button)

description: Text buttons are text labels that fall outside of a block of text. The text should describe the action that will occur if a user clicks or taps a button. Text buttons have a low level of emphasis and are typically used for less important actions. Because text buttons don’t have a container, they don’t distract from nearby content. When you want to use a tertiairy button as a return button, point the arrow to the left.
name: Text buttons and links

description: Text buttons are text labels that fall outside of a block of text. The text should describe the action that will occur if a user clicks or taps a button. Text buttons have a low level of emphasis and are typically used for less important actions. Because text buttons don’t have a container, they don’t distract from nearby content. When you want to use a tertiairy button as a return button, point the arrow to the left.
name: Text buttons and links

description: For usage in bodytext when links are needed
name: Text links

description: Mostly used to indicate engaging / disengaging certain feature within the context.
name: Toggle

description: Used in the situation when desired state of preference needs to be selected. Only one selection can be made at all times. When mutiple preferences need to be chosen use checkboxes instead.
name: Radio button

description: Checkboxes can be used when a desired items needs to be selected. Depending on the context it can be one or multiple items.
name: Checkbox

description: Button group for desktop and tablet
name: Desktop and tablet

description: Button group for mobile
name: Mobile
Colors
description: We lead with white to reflect confidence, transparency and premiumness. It provides air and space as well as allows the eye to focus on what is important.

The primary colors define our brand expression and our brand core is white, blue and yellow.
The balance between our primary and secondary colors are 80/20, and we always lead with our primary colors.
name: Primary colors

description: These colors are to be used in graphs, illustrations and infographics only. Some are allowed to be used as UX color; for example green an red.
name: Secondary colors

description: When creating 1-coloured graphs, you should primarily use these percent-values to differentiate sections of the graph. This is exemplified below in Vattenfall Pink, but you can use any of the primary or secondary colors as a base.
name: Color tones

description: The tertiary colors are mainly grey tints. We use ‘Lighter Grey’ for 1px horizontal borders and the ‘Light Grey’ for inputfield borders.
name: Tertiary

description: Recommended colours for specific energy sources has been developed mainly to be used for information graphs. Please note that this is a recommendation and not a rule. Colour coding for regulation compliance. The categories are: Renewable, Nuclear, District heating and Fossil.
name: Energy source colors

description: Sometimes lines are used to seperate planes from eachother. Depending on the background the following colors are used for lines
name: Lines
Forms
description: Input text are the most commently use form control. Input fields are suitable for getting textual data from the user.

Dropdown is an element that allows you to make a particular choice within compact area which is very useful, especially for the mobile devices. Only one item can be chosen at the time. Advice is to use this element when the amount of items to be chosen from exceeds 3 options.
name: Dropdown

description: Underline input is only used when the input fields are three or less. Distance between each field should always be 28px
name: Underline input

description: Number input should alwasy be 52px in height. Like dropdowns, numbers include an ever-present label in order to be accessible.
name: number

description: Tooltips appear on hover and provide an additional layer of information for the user. They are filled with different colors in order to generate maximum contrast with the page beneath. Carets are positioned in the top center, bottom center, right center and left center
name: Textarea

description: Textarea provides the possibility for the custom input from the user. Use this element when personal feedback from the user is needed or the situation itself is not specific enough to support pre-definied option for the user to choose from.
name: Tooltip
Hero
description: The Hero component is used for large blocks at the top of webpages to convey a key message or describe what the page is about.

The Hero module with video content is used mainly for pages that need to relate back to and anchor the connection with our external video content / campaigns.The headline should always be over two lines and displaying a play button 44px below. Headline and play button should both be vertically aligned and centered over the video and should not use drop shadows.
name: Hero with video

description: The Hero module with Video content and the Vattenfall stacked logotype should be used for Vattenfall Startpages only and not elsewhere.
name: For Startpage (only)

description: The Hero module should be used when only one row of headline text is needed.
name: 1 text line

description: The Hero module should be used as in the example for one row of text over image with a CTA button
name: 1 text line + Button

description: The Hero module should be used as in the example, when two rows of text over image with CTA button is needed.
name: 2 text lines + Button

description: The Hero module should be used as in the example, when two rows of headline text is needed.
name: 2 text line

description: The Hero module should be used as in the example when Headline, Intro text and Buttons are needed.
name: Text + Intro + Buttons
Icons
description: The icons mirror our typeface – engineered and human, confident and determined.
Action icons are used to signal and describe interaction.
name: Action icons

description: These are specific Icons for InCharge.
name: Incharge icons

description: Identification icons are used to identify a service or product.
name: Identification icons

description: Identification icons are used to identify a service or product.
name: Navigation icons

description: Smart home icons are used to identify products and services for the home.
name: Smart home icons

description: Social media icons do not adhere to our icon style since they are logotypes and symbol of other platforms and services.
name: Social media icons

description: Functional – our main illustration style and most frequently used. The inspiration comes from technical drawings and blueprints.
name: Functional

description: In illustrations the full scale of colors may be used, but in a moderate way. Try not to use more than three colors in a single illustration, this for not be percived as childish or too colorful.
name: Key principles

description: To illustrate new isometric illustrations you can use the grid bellow. You find it under Utility / Isometric Grid - Illustrations in our Ui Kit.
name: Grid

description: Sharing information and data in a clear and confident wy is part of the Vettenfall overall tonality, and graphs are a key graphics elements to make data come alive. Vattenfall has a style for information graphics that is bold, simple and clear To create the graphics, the Vattenfall colours can be used in different ways - please read more regarding color usage below.
name: Information graphics style

description: There are different types of charts and graphs to be used - pie charts, bar graphs and lines graphs. They are generally used for different things. Pie charts show how a whole is divided into different parts, bar graphs show numbers that are independent of each other and line graphs show numbers that have changed over time.
name: Types of graphs

description: When creating information graphics mainly use the secondary colours, but the primary colours are also allowed. There is also a colour palette specifically made for the different energy sources. Please look further down on this page to see how to use these colors and to find the colour codes. The color black is only used in text an lines, not as a color in the graph or chart.
name: Colours for graphs

description: Recommended colours for specific energy sources has been developed mainly to be used for information graphs. Please note that this is a recommendation and not a rule. Colour coding for refulation compliance. The categories are: Renewable, Nuclear, District heating and Fossil.
name: Energy source colours

description: When creating information graphics mainly use the secondary colours, but the primary colours are also allowed.Either create graphics using colours tones in the same colour range or use colours in the same category: secondary, primary or energy source colours.
name: Colour usage

description: When creating 1-coloured graphs, you should primarily use these percent-values to differentiate sections of the graph. This is exemplified below but you can use any primary or secondary colours as a base.
name: Colour tones for web

description: Always place information graphics on white or Vattenfall Light Grey background. Do not place multi-coloured graphs on coloured backgrounds.
name: Background colours

description: Always place information graphics on white or Vattenfall Light Grey background. Do not place multi-coloured graphs on coloured backgrounds.
name: Best practice

description: Infographics is of course the visualization of data in graphs, tables and numbers. Through our motion ID philosophy of “ease-in-out”, infographics actually become the most powerful examples of our identity in motion as we here allow a graph or number to develop in a smooth, controlled “easing” movement with a high-quality perception.
name: Infographics motion
Logotype
description: The logotype consists of two parts, the wordmark "Vattenfall" and the yellow/blue symbol. The wordmark has been modernised, but kept in capital letters to reflect the confident leadership that Vattenfall takes towards a fossil free future. The symbol balances the wordmark with the organic, round shape, visually enhancing a global aspiration to be a rolemodel for sustainable change.
The Vattenfall logotype consists of two parts, the wordmark "Vattenfall" and the yellow / blue symbol.
name: Key principles

description: The Vattenfall linear logotype and the Vattenfall stacked logotype are available in two different versions; the primary logotype and the 1-colored logotype. The primary logotype has colored symbol and is available wit grey, black or negative wordmark. The 1-colored logotype has both symbol and wordmark in one color, either black or negative.
name: Color version

description: The clearspace around the linear logotype is defined by the Vattenfall Symbol. The symbol is 1X, and the clearspace is 1x around all sides of the logotype.
name: Linear - logos / horizontal / medium

description: The clearspace around the logotype is half of the symbols height (1X). The clearspace is 1X around all sides of the logotype.
name: Stacked - logos / stacked
Motion
description: When designing with Vttenfall Digital Design System,make sure to think trough th motion effects and transitions that are included to it. Watch over the purpose of ech effect and do not combine several components with heavy animations at once: the digitl behaviour of such should bring liveliness and sbtle motion rather than chaotic movement

name: Navigation
description: Navigation

name: Spacers
description: The Spacers come in four sizes, Small 28px, Medium 44px, Large 56px and Extra Large 88px. You'll find them under Utility in the library. Important to note is that all distances between individual modules are 88px aka the "Spacer - Extra Large" on the desktop and 28ps on Mobile.
Example of applied spacers in the Image block Module. To visually see the spacers, turn on eye symbol inside of "Utility /Spacers"
name: Example - desktop

description: Example of applied spacers in the Image block Mobile Module. To visually see the spacers, turn on eye symbol inside of "Utility / Spacers"
name: Example - mobile

description: Important to note is that all distances between individual modules are 88px ka the "Spacer - Extra Large" on desktop. Exception is for the modules named "media block" with image that hangs down,then use 2 of the 88px spacers.
name: Distance between modules - desktop
Spinner
description: Spinner

name: Typography
description: Hall is a bespoke typeface that mirrors and embodies the qualities of a true market leader – as expected by our target group: confident, competent and determined. Yet, it should feel stable, organic, and personable and at the same time emphasise our engineering and functional capacity. Being bold without being arrogant, it creates credibility for our capability to act on on a broader scale. Developed together with the wordmark and icons, it creates a strong, recognisable and coherent identity.
Always use Hall Display Bold for 30px and above. Always use Hall Bold for under 30px
name: Rules for headings

description: Should always be used for titles of top-level sections of a screen. Primarily used for Marquee/Hero sections.
name: Header H1

description: Primarily used for secondary sections inside content area.
name: Header H2

description: Primarily used for tetriary sections inside content area.
name: Header H3

description: Primarily used for quarternary sections inside content area.
name: Header H4

description: This is Preamble copy. Used for introducing the content after a Headline.
name: Preamble text

description: This is a large body copy. This is our main body text used on the website.
name: Body text large

description: This is body text small and is used in all of vattenfalls modules as bodttext.
name: Body text small

description: THIS IS OUR intro in caps and is used on the three first words together with body text large.
name: Intro in caps
Upload
description: Upload
